This requirement regarding different mechanism levels (or organizational levels) is generally accepted in biological sciences, where interdisciplinary studies and inter-level theories focusing on the relationships between mechanisms at different levels are common (e.g. Wimsatt, 2007). In accordance with this view, Hedström & Ylikoski (2010: 60) write as follows: ‘Rather than relying on some preconceived ideas about human motivation or cognitive processing, the mechanism-based perspective suggests that our account of human agency should be based on findings and theories of psychological and cognitive sciences.’

Recently, Hedström & Bearman (2009: 10–13) have used the term ‘supervenience’ to describe ontological relations between ‘micro- and macro-properties of collectives’. Though this term has been widely used in philosophy of mind, I doubt whether it enables us to better understand the nature of social phenomena, since supervenience is a purely formal relation between two sets of properties that does not say anything about the nature of different kind of collectives (except that their macro-properties supervene upon some unspecified sets of micro-properties) or how they are brought about and sustained. Application of the term ‘supervenience’ to some real collective also presupposes that we have a complete characterization of all of its micro-properties P that allegedly constitute the supervenience base for its macro-property M. I doubt that this rather metaphysical requirement can ever be met in real-world cases.

It may be added that the DBO theory ignores creative action, but since this phenomenon is somewhat ambiguous and difficult to conceptualize, I decided to exclude discussion of it (for an interesting theoretical account of creative action, however, see Joas, 1996).

Hutchins (1995: xiii) writes, for example, that ‘[d]epending on their mode of organization, groups must have cognitive properties that are not predictable from a knowledge of the properties of the individuals in the group’. When speaking about the division of cognitive labour in groups, he also suggests that ‘the group performing the cognitive task may have cognitive properties that differ from the cognitive properties of any individual’ (1995: 176). Clark (1997: 84) writes accordingly that to ‘take body and world seriously [in human cognition] is to invite an emergentist perspective on many key phenomena – to see adaptive success as inhering as much in the complex interactions among body, world, and brain as in the inner processes bounded by skin and skull’. In my view, these statements and Hutchins’s (1995) notion of distributed cognitive systems presuppose an ontological concept of emergence, which can be clarified by employing Wimsatt’s (e.g. 2007, chap. 12) account of the concept of emergence in terms of the failure of aggregativity of a system property. In this view, emergent properties are properties of a system (with respect to a certain decomposition) that are not possessed by its component parts and cannot be derived by aggregating the properties of its isolated parts. Wimsatt (2007: 280–281) presents four conditions of an aggregativity of a system property, which he calls (i) inter-substitution, (ii) size scaling, (iii) decomposition and reaggregation, and (iv) linearity. This view entails both that emergent properties of a system break one or more of these conditions and are ontologically dependent on the mode of organization of the system (2007: 276). Though Wimsatt denies the possibility of eliminating emergent properties from scientific ontology, he does not deny the possibility of explaining emergent properties scientifically by taking into account the system’s components (including their properties) as well as their interactions and relations to the system’s environment. His concept of emergence can be thus characterized as a weak form of ontological emergence because it does not deny the possibility of explaining emergent properties. Theiner, Allen & Goldstone (2010: 381–383) have recently applied Wimsatt’s concept of emergence to the phenomenon of group cognition, and I have elsewhere argued that his gradual approach to emergence can be fruitfully employed in social ontology (Kaidesoja, 2009, 2012).

I use the terms ‘extended cognitive system’ and ‘extended mind’ (e.g. Clark, 1997, 2008; Clark & Chalmers, 1998) to refer primarily to systems that are composed of a person and his/her cognitive artifact(s) since this type of phenomena are mostly discussed in the philosophical literature on extended mind. As indicated above, the term ‘distributed cognitive system’, by contrast, always involves a social dimension. Since my focus is on studies on distributed cognition, I largely omit the philosophical disputes related to the extended mind.
This process differs from Hedström’s (2005: 47–49) notion of rational imitation since rational imitation occurs via the actor’s decision to imitate the actions of others.

bio.title: Author biography
bio.p: Tuukka Kaidesoja is a post-doctoral researcher in the Philosophy of Social Sciences at the Finnish Academy Centre of Excellence, University of Helsinki. His research interests include analytical sociology, critical realism, distributed cognition, and systemic social ontology and methodology.
